rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (light techno music)}
{\rtf1 - In this lab, what we're\par doing is getting you used to}
{\rtf1 different ways of picking up logs.}
{\rtf1 Specifically we're going\par to do three different ways}
{\rtf1 of picking up logs.}
{\rtf1 We're going to monitor a folder\par for logs to be put into it.}
{\rtf1 We're also going to try using UDP and TCP.}
{\rtf1 Now this is important\par 'cause I want you to get}
{\rtf1 in a habit of knowing\par how to manually interact}
{\rtf1 with different components of a sim,}
{\rtf1 and the advantages it might bring you.}
{\rtf1 For example, in this lab,}
{\rtf1 you're going to bring in connections\par over a TCP port, or a UDP.}
{\rtf1 One is going to be\par connection-oriented, one is not.}
{\rtf1 Also you're going to see that\par you can pick an arbitrary port.}
{\rtf1 This means you could cheat and say}
{\rtf1 any application coming in\par over this arbitrary port,}
{\rtf1 must be this application.}
{\rtf1 And in that case you actually\par can gain a performance boost}
{\rtf1 by choosing a port per application.}
{\rtf1 There's different ways\par of doing everything,}
{\rtf1 so this is to start getting\par you comfortable in doing that.}
{\rtf1 In step one, the first\par thing we're going to do,}
{\rtf1 is we're going to use\par Visual Studio Code editor}
{\rtf1 to create a Logstash configuration file.}
{\rtf1 In this configuration file,\par what we're going to be doing,}
{\rtf1 is monitoring a file.}
{\rtf1 Specifically we're going to say}
{\rtf1 any logs that get dropped into this file,}
{\rtf1 we're going to pick up as\par if we're ingesting them}
{\rtf1 into the sim.}
{\rtf1 We're going to print these out\par to screen using standard out,}
{\rtf1 just so you can see that\par this is working properly.}
{\rtf1 We're going to save\par the configuration file,}
{\rtf1 and then the next thing we're\par going to do is in the terminal,}
{\rtf1 we're going to run Logstash\par using this configuration file}
{\rtf1 we just created.}
{\rtf1 When you first start Logstash,}
{\rtf1 just know it may take a second\par 'cause Logstash uses Java,}
{\rtf1 so its startup times can\par be just a little bit.}
{\rtf1 You'll know Logstash is\par running when you see,}
{\rtf1 pipelines running.}
{\rtf1 At that point your configuration\par file has been loaded}
{\rtf1 and you are ready to go.}
{\rtf1 To see that it's working\par though, what we need to do,}
{\rtf1 is give Logstash files.}
{\rtf1 Log files.}
{\rtf1 'Cause remember, the first\par configuration we're doing,}
{\rtf1 is to tell it to monitor\par a directory for logs.}
{\rtf1 We're going to open a second terminal,}
{\rtf1 and in the second terminal,}
{\rtf1 we're going to copy some logs\par that already were on the box,}
{\rtf1 into the folder Logstash is monitoring.}
{\rtf1 When you do so, flip back\par to the Logstash terminal,}
{\rtf1 and you should see them\par being printed to the screen.}
{\rtf1 'Cause in step one we're\par not sending the logs}
{\rtf1 in the back end storage,}
{\rtf1 we're really just\par getting used to debugging}
{\rtf1 and troubleshooting or\par manually building out}
{\rtf1 new configuration files for Logstash.}
{\rtf1 In the Logstash terminal,}
{\rtf1 go ahead and push Control\par + c on your keyboard.}
{\rtf1 This will go ahead and stop Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Now, in step two, what we're\par trying to do is bring logs in,}
{\rtf1 but this time instead\par of monitoring a folder,}
{\rtf1 we want them to come in over the network.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to use UDP\par 1055, or one thousand 55,}
{\rtf1 to bring logs in.}
{\rtf1 Start by building a\par new configuration file.}
{\rtf1 We'll call this UDP 1055.com}
{\rtf1 and in this configuration\par file, what we're going to do,}
{\rtf1 is instead of having an input of files,}
{\rtf1 we're going to have an input\par of UDP and specify port 1,055.}
{\rtf1 This is going to allow\par Logstash to listen on UDP 1055,}
{\rtf1 waiting for logs to come inbound.}
{\rtf1 We're going to go ahead and\par save this configuration file,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to run it using Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Again, you have to wait\par for pipelines running}
{\rtf1 to know that Logstash\par is fully up and running.}
{\rtf1 At this point,}
{\rtf1 what we're going to do is flip\par back to the purple terminal,}
{\rtf1 or the agent terminal,}
{\rtf1 and what we're going to\par do is we're going to build}
{\rtf1 a configuration file\par for NXLog, a log agent,}
{\rtf1 to ship logs via UDP.}
{\rtf1 We're going to create the\par configuration file for a log agent.}
{\rtf1 In this case the black terminal\par is simulating Logstash,}
{\rtf1 the purple terminal is going\par to be simulating a log agent,}
{\rtf1 in this case NXLog.}
{\rtf1 In the configuration file for NXLog,}
{\rtf1 all's we're actually saying is,}
{\rtf1 hey, pick up the auth.log\par file on the system,}
{\rtf1 and ship that over the\par network via UDP port 1,055.}
{\rtf1 That's all we're doing.}
{\rtf1 This would be a production config.}
{\rtf1 The only difference is,}
{\rtf1 is we're staging the auth log\par file from the lab directory.}
{\rtf1 Save this configuration file\par and in the purple terminal,}
{\rtf1 we're going to run NXLog Processor.}
{\rtf1 This is a command line\par instance of the agent}
{\rtf1 that will send all the logs and then stop.}
{\rtf1 Go ahead and run that,}
{\rtf1 and when you switch back\par to the black terminal,}
{\rtf1 you should see the logs coming in,}
{\rtf1 but this time they came via UDP 1,055.}
{\rtf1 Use Control + c on your\par keyboard to stop Logstash again,}
{\rtf1 and you've got UDP logs\par coming in over UDP.}
{\rtf1 Next what we're going to do\par is bring in logs over TCP}
{\rtf1 instead of UDP.}
{\rtf1 Again we're going to open\par up a new configuration file}
{\rtf1 with Visual Studio Code,}
{\rtf1 and in here, it's almost\par identical to the last step.}
{\rtf1 The only difference is\par instead of doing UDP,}
{\rtf1 we're going to use TCP.}
{\rtf1 And this time we're\par going to use port 1,056.}
{\rtf1 We're going to go ahead and\par save that configuration file,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to run Logstash}
{\rtf1 pointing at that new configuration file.}
{\rtf1 Now in the black terminal,}
{\rtf1 we have Logstash listening\par on TCP port 1056,}
{\rtf1 and now we just need to get logs to it.}
{\rtf1 Again we could use a\par log agent such as NXLog,}
{\rtf1 but I just want to show\par different ways of doing this.}
{\rtf1 Now in the purple\par terminal, switch to that,}
{\rtf1 and what we're going to do\par is we're going to just use}
{\rtf1 the built in Netcat utility, or NC,}
{\rtf1 to bring in logs over TCP.}
{\rtf1 We're going to run Netcat.}
{\rtf1 We're going to have it read in\par auth.log off the file system}
{\rtf1 and then just send it over\par the network on TCP port 1056.}
{\rtf1 Again, in the Logstash terminal}
{\rtf1 you'll see those logs coming in,}
{\rtf1 showing that it is working correctly.}
{\rtf1 Once you see those logs coming in, again,}
{\rtf1 go ahead and hit Control\par + c to stop Logstash.}
{\rtf1 The ultimate goal of bringing logs in,}
{\rtf1 is to get them in the back end storage}
{\rtf1 so you can start analyzing them.}
{\rtf1 In the previous steps we've\par played with just different}
{\rtf1 ways of bringing in logs\par into the aggregator,}
{\rtf1 but now we need to get them into storage.}
{\rtf1 For this what we're going\par to do is just create}
{\rtf1 a new configuration file,}
{\rtf1 but we're going to use TCP 1,056 again,}
{\rtf1 but this time instead of having\par the log go out to screen,}
{\rtf1 we're going to bring them\par into the back end storage.}
{\rtf1 Which in our case is Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 In Visual Studio Code we'll\par create a new configuration file}
{\rtf1 and you'll see the only\par real difference here}
{\rtf1 is in the output section,}
{\rtf1 we're using Elasticsearch,\par instead of standard out.}
{\rtf1 Go ahead and save the configuration}
{\rtf1 and we're going to load it into Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Once you see pipelines running,\par Logstash is ready to go,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to run Netcat\par again in the purple terminal.}
{\rtf1 In the purple terminal\par when you run Netcat,}
{\rtf1 it's going to be sending logs\par via TCP port 1,056 into Logstash.}
{\rtf1 But this time when you go to\par look at the Logstash terminal,}
{\rtf1 there's no logs there.}
{\rtf1 It's just the same screen,\par the pipelines running,}
{\rtf1 and that's it.}
{\rtf1 The reason being is this time,}
{\rtf1 the logs are going to Elasticsearch,}
{\rtf1 not standard out to console.}
{\rtf1 So that is the expectation.}
{\rtf1 You technically could have it do both}
{\rtf1 just by putting them both\par in the output section,}
{\rtf1 but I'm just showing you\par what this is occurring.}
{\rtf1 We want to stop Logstash when\par we're done but the question is,}
{\rtf1 how do you know that you are done}
{\rtf1 and you have received the logs?}
{\rtf1 For this in the purple terminal,}
{\rtf1 once Netcat is done\par sending logs to Logstash,}
{\rtf1 it'll return to the\par command prompt by itself.}
{\rtf1 Once it's done that you\par can switch back to Logstash}
{\rtf1 and hit Control + c to stop Logstash.}
{\rtf1 At this point you have\par logs that went from Netcat,}
{\rtf1 simulating a logging agent,\par to Logstash an aggregator,}
{\rtf1 and then Logstash shoved\par them into Elasticsearch,}
{\rtf1 your back end storage system.}
{\rtf1 The last step in this\par lab is just to verify}
{\rtf1 that we can access the logs we ingested.}
{\rtf1 To do this we're going to make\par sure that Kibana can see them.}
{\rtf1 Kibana's going to be the GUI\par program we'll use for this class.}
{\rtf1 To do this what you're going to do,}
{\rtf1 is you're going to open up Firefox}
{\rtf1 and in Firefox there's a\par bookmark called Kibana.}
{\rtf1 Click on that and it's\par going to load up Kibana.}
{\rtf1 Before we can start searching the logs,}
{\rtf1 we have to let Kibana\par know how to query them.}
{\rtf1 To do this we're going\par to click on management,}
{\rtf1 and under management\par we're going to click on}
{\rtf1 the index patterns link.}
{\rtf1 In here is all the list of\par indexes that it's aware of}
{\rtf1 and can search.}
{\rtf1 For us to search these new\par ones we need to click on}
{\rtf1 create index pattern.}
{\rtf1 From here we're going to\par specify what index we stored}
{\rtf1 the logs into.}
{\rtf1 And if you remember your\par Logstash configuration file}
{\rtf1 we used, we simply created an index}
{\rtf1 called lab one dot two.}
{\rtf1 Go ahead and type in lab one\par dot two for the index pattern.}
{\rtf1 Click on next and for the time field,}
{\rtf1 we're going to select, at time stamp.}
{\rtf1 This is just letting it know\par when we search via time,}
{\rtf1 what field it's using\par for that time source.}
{\rtf1 Then we're going to create this pattern,}
{\rtf1 and now Kibana is aware of and knows how}
{\rtf1 to search that index.}
{\rtf1 This means we can switch\par back to the discover tab,}
{\rtf1 click the drop down for indexes,}
{\rtf1 and we can select lab two dot one}
{\rtf1 and you should be able to see your logs.}
{\rtf1 If you can't see the logs,}
{\rtf1 it's probably in the top right corner.}
{\rtf1 The time that's selected,}
{\rtf1 might say the last 15 minutes}
{\rtf1 and maybe you ingested\par the logs 30 minutes ago.}
{\rtf1 So you can play with the time,}
{\rtf1 maybe say last five years,\par just to show all time,}
{\rtf1 and then you should be able to\par see the logs we've brought in}
{\rtf1 from the previous steps.}
{\rtf1 In this lab we basically brought in logs}
{\rtf1 via monitoring a folder,}
{\rtf1 or we could have done individual files.}
{\rtf1 We brought in logs via UDP and TCP,}
{\rtf1 and ultimately we made sure that they hit}
{\rtf1 the back end storage and\par that we could search them.}
{\rtf1 This hopefully is getting\par you more comfortable}
{\rtf1 with how the sim handles ingestion,}
{\rtf1 and that you really kind\par of have multiple options.}
{\rtf1 We're going to continue\par doing this with more labs}
{\rtf1 but get comfortable\par with how your sim works}
{\rtf1 and the different options available to you}
{\rtf1 for bringing in those logs.}
